abstract.p: Susan Novick reviews Robinson's Tea Room in Stony Brook, NY (Quick Bite column) (S)

block.p: Robinson's Tea Room near the village green in Stony Brook is as dainty as a dollhouse, with 12 chintz-covered tables and garlands of silk gardenias draped over the lace curtains. Loretta and James Vertucci, the owners, have a ''Shelf of Fame'' where teacups used by visiting celebrities like Yoko Ono have been retired and displayed; there is also a collection of teapots for sale.

Robinson's offers more than 80 varieties of fresh-brewed teas, which range from delicate Jasmine Blossom to robust French caramel crème brûlée. The full British afternoon tea service ($23) includes unlimited tea -- you may sample more than one flavor -- which arrives with a tiered rack containing scones, tea sandwiches and pastries. Your choice of scone (cinnamon, raisin or orange-cranberry), comes with fresh clotted cream and raspberry jam. The assorted tea sandwiches include shrimp, tuna, ham, cucumber and turkey, along with a miniature quiche. The desserts are a custard and fruit tart, a white chocolate mousse tart and a rolled pirouline cookie with hazelnut cream.

Robinson's also has an extensive light breakfast and lunch menu featuring salads ($7.95 to $13.95), wraps ($7.95 to $8.95) and other sandwiches ($5.75 to $7.95). The children's menu has a few playful surprises: mixed in with the grilled cheese and chicken nuggets is a nutella-and-marshmallow-fluff sandwich ($5, served with juice or a little pot of tea).
An individual pot of tea (two to three cups) à la carte is $3, a large pot (six cups), $5. Cakes and scones are also sold à la carte, and loose tea is sold by the pound ($16 to $34).
Reservations are essential for the afternoon tea, although breakfast and lunch patrons are seated first come first served.
Robinson's Tea Room, Stony Brook Village Center, 97E Main Street, Stony Brook; (631) 751-1232. Open Tuesday to Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.
